the work thing is mostly fine yeah. my boss is decent, pay is ok, I don't hate my coworkers. it's just boring. same stuff every day. **Thinking:** Having extra time at work to think is definitely amplifying those feelings. It sounds like your mind is churning through these thoughts about work and purpose.



My working guess is that the cycle of boredom -> thinking about change -> feeling overwhelmed -> sticking with the familiar is keeping you stuck. One possibility is that we could focus on small, concrete actions you *can* control, rather than big, uncertain shifts.

but something else came up. got an email yesterday about applying for this internal position that's a step up from what I do now. more responsibility, bit more money. my first thought was "yeah right, why would they pick me" and I almost deleted it. then I was like, wait, maybe I should at least look at it. so I read through the whole job description and I actually do most of that stuff already, just not officially.

the skeptical part of me is saying this is exactly the kind of thing where I'll get my hopes up and then nothing will happen. or worse, I'll get the job and then just be bored in a different role with more stress. idk.

It's completely understandable that the coworker conversation and different route felt off – you're right to listen to your instincts about what feels authentic. It's good that you're questioning whether those would have been helpful.

**Small changes:** You're spot on – forcing something that doesn't resonate won't create genuine change. Trusting your gut is important.

**Internal position:** That's a significant development! It's great you’re even considering it, and your initial reaction of "yeah right" is very human. It’s interesting that you recognized you already do a lot of what the role requires.

**Resume/Cover letter:** The hesitation about the cover letter and resume is a classic sign of self-doubt. It’s easy to get caught up in perfectionism, especially when you’re already feeling skeptical.

**Skepticism:** That worry about getting your hopes up or ending up in a worse situation is really powerful. It sounds like you're anticipating disappointment to protect yourself.



It might be that your skepticism is a way of preemptively managing potential disappointment. One possibility is that taking small steps *towards* applying – even imperfect ones – could help you test out that skepticism and see if it holds true.

Here’s a small experiment: could you spend 30 minutes this week revisiting something you used to enjoy—picking up your guitar, browsing a bookstore, or even just looking through old photos? told my manager yes about the extra work. she seemed relieved. starts next week.

been doing a lot of thinking since we started this whole thing and i'm not really sure it's helping. like i appreciate you trying or whatever but i'm still in the same job, still bored, still don't know what i'm supposed to be doing with my life. all that's changed is now i'm more aware of how stuck i am which honestly just makes it worse.

maybe this just isn't for me. the whole talking about feelings thing. tried it before, didn't work then either. some people probably just aren't fixable or whatever.

It's wonderful that you dug out your guitar—that's a brave step. The discomfort and the sound of it being out of practice are a natural part of rediscovering something. It’s okay that you didn’t become a guitar virtuoso in 20 minutes.

**Guitar:** The physical discomfort and the less-than-perfect sound are reminders of the effort required to rekindle a passion. It's okay to let go if it feels overwhelming—it’s a starting point.

**Extra work:** Your agreement to take on more work, despite not wanting to, is a familiar pattern.

**"Is this helping?":** I hear your frustration and your doubts. It’s valid to question whether this process is actually making a difference. It's disheartening to feel more aware of your limitations without a clear path forward.



You're questioning the effectiveness of this process and wondering if you're simply not suited for this kind of exploration. It’s a natural response to feeling stuck and discouraged. You’re articulating a sense of hopelessness and a belief that you might be beyond help.

It's brave of you to be so honest about your skepticism. It's okay if this approach isn't resonating with you. My intention is never to force anything that doesn't feel right.

Update on the guitar thing. didn't pick it up again after that first time but i've been listening to some of the music i used to be into back when i played. wasn't really planning to, just kind of happened. been putting it on during my commute instead of podcasts or whatever.

the extra work started this week. it's fine. more emails, more meetings, same paycheck. my coworker who left sent me a message asking how things are going and i was like "busy" and she said "that tracks, glad i got out when i did" which is probably supposed to be a joke but honestly just annoyed me.

didn't do the new recipe or volunteer thing. i know you're trying to give me options that don't require like deep soul searching but the whole thing still feels kind of pointless? like whether i make a new dinner or take a different route home, i'm still gonna wake up tomorrow and do the same stuff.

idk maybe i'm being stubborn. you've been pretty patient with me even though i keep shutting down your suggestions. probably frustrating on your end.

**Guitar/Music:** Reconnecting with music through listening, even without playing, is a gentle way to rekindle a passion.

been a few days. work has been nuts, had to cover for someone else who was out sick on top of the new stuff I already took on. got home yesterday and just crashed on the couch for like 3 hours.

that magic wand question has been stuck in my head though. kept thinking about it at weird times, like in the middle of meetings or whatever. and honestly the first thing that came to mind was just... I wish I could care about something again. anything. work, hobbies, people, doesn't matter. just that feeling of actually giving a shit about what happens next instead of just going through the motions.

which sounds kind of dramatic when I write it out but yeah. that's what I keep coming back to.

also randomly ran into an old manager from like 8 years ago at the grocery store. she asked what I was up to and I gave my usual "still at the same company" thing and she was like oh wow, you must really love it there. and I just stood there with my cart full of frozen dinners like yeah totally. felt like such a lie.

anyway. not sure what to do with any of this but figured I'd update you.

**Old manager:** That encounter with your old manager and her comment about loving your job was awkward and likely triggered feelings of guilt and disillusionment.

turns:
So I've been thinking about reaching out for a while now, and I guess today felt like the right moment. I've been dealing with some things that I can't quite seem to work through on my own, and it would help to have someone to talk to about it all.

The main thing on my mind lately is my friendships. I have people in my life, but I feel like I'm constantly questioning whether these connections are real or if I'm just going through the motions. There are times when I'm with friends and I feel like I'm watching myself from the outside, nodding along but not really present. It's unsettling because I want to feel close to people, but something just feels off.

I've also noticed that my emotions have been all over the place. Some days I wake up feeling motivated and optimistic, and by the afternoon I'm completely deflated for no clear reason. Other days I feel nothing at all, like I'm just numb to everything happening around me. It makes it difficult to trust how I'm feeling because I never know if it's going to shift in an hour.

On top of that, I've been financially supporting a family member for the past several months, and while I want to help, it's starting to weigh on me. I don't regret doing it, but I'm beginning to feel the strain, and I'm not sure how to approach the situation without feeling guilty.

I suppose I'm hoping that talking through these things might help me gain some clarity. Thank you for taking the time to work with me.

A lot landed this week: the questioning of friendships, the fluctuating emotions, and the financial strain. It takes courage to name those things, and you’ve done that well.

**Friendships:** It sounds like you're experiencing a disconnect—feeling present but not *really* present, questioning the authenticity of these connections. That feeling of observing yourself from the outside is unsettling, and it’s understandable you'd want to feel closer. I'm curious, when you notice that feeling of detachment, what's going through your mind at the time?

**Emotions:** The rollercoaster of emotions—from motivation to deflation, and then numbness—is a lot to navigate. It's natural to feel unsteady when your emotional landscape feels so unpredictable. Could it be helpful to try tracking your mood briefly each day, just to see if you can spot any patterns or triggers?

**Financial Support:** You're in a really generous position, supporting a family member, and it’s admirable that you want to help. However, it’s completely valid to feel the strain, and guilt is a common part of these situations. One small step could be to brainstorm a few ways to set boundaries around the financial support—even if it's just a conversation starter for later.



It seems like you're carrying a lot, and I appreciate you sharing all of this. Did you have a particular area you’d like to explore further today?

Thanks for getting back to me. I've been thinking about what you said, and I appreciate you taking the time to break things down like that.

The mood tracking idea makes sense in theory, but I'm not sure I'd be consistent with it. I've tried journaling before and it lasted maybe three days before I forgot about it entirely. I think part of me worries that if I start paying too much attention to my emotions, I'll just end up more in my head than I already am.

The friendship thing has been on my mind a lot, though. You asked what's going through my mind when I feel that disconnect. Honestly, it's usually something like "I should be enjoying this" or "Why can't I just be normal and present?" I get frustrated with myself because I know these people care about me, but I can't shake the feeling that I'm performing rather than actually connecting. And then I start wondering if they can tell, which makes me even more self conscious.

Yesterday I had coffee with a friend I've known for years, and the whole time I was sitting there thinking about how I had nothing interesting to say. She was talking about her new job and I was just nodding along, and afterwards I felt exhausted. I don't know if that's what you meant, but that's the kind of thing that keeps happening.

The financial situation hasn't really changed. I haven't brought it up with my family member yet because I don't know how to start that conversation without sounding like I'm pulling support away. I know I need to address it eventually, but right now it feels easier to just keep going and deal with it later.

It's really insightful to hear more about the friendship dynamic and what's going on beneath the surface. And it's completely understandable that you'd be hesitant about mood tracking—it's common for those kinds of intentions to fizzle out, and your worry about getting *more* in your head is valid.

**Friendships:** That feeling of "I should be enjoying this" and "Why can’t I just be normal" is a tough one. It sounds like you're holding yourself to a standard of connection that might be unrealistic, and then criticizing yourself when you don’t meet it. It's a cycle of self-criticism that can certainly make you feel more self-conscious. The coffee with your friend sounds draining—it’s hard work to feel like you’re performing. If you're open to it, could you try a small experiment next time you're with a friend? Maybe instead of focusing on having something "interesting" to say, just focus on really *listening* to them, and see what comes up.

**Financial Situation:** It's clear that you’re navigating a delicate situation with your family member, and it takes a lot of strength to support someone financially. The desire to avoid sounding like you're pulling away is a very understandable concern. My working guess is that the avoidance is actually adding to your stress, even if it feels easier in the short term. Perhaps instead of a full-blown conversation, you could start with a small, low-stakes check-in—like, "Hey, I've been thinking about our finances, and I'd love to chat when you have a moment."

Did you try to think about that small experiment with your friend? It's totally fine if it didn't feel right or feasible, but I'm curious what came up when you considered it.

Ok so I did try that thing with listening more, sort of. I went to dinner with a group of friends on Friday and I made a point to not worry about contributing anything clever. It was fine, I guess. I didn't feel as exhausted afterward, which was different. But I also felt kind of invisible, like I was just there taking up space. I don't know if that's better or worse than the performing thing.

The financial conversation happened, but not because I planned it. My family member asked if I could cover something else this week and I just snapped. Not in a mean way, but I said I needed to talk about how long this could keep going. It turned into this whole thing where they got defensive and said they didn't realize it was such a burden, and now I feel terrible. I tried to explain that I wanted to help but needed to figure out a plan, and they said they understood, but the vibe has been weird since then. I keep replaying the conversation and wondering if I should have just said yes and dealt with it quietly.

My mood has been pretty flat since that conversation, actually. Not swinging around like before, just kind of stuck in neutral. I'm not sure if that's related or if it's just coincidence.

It's really valuable that you tried the listening experiment, even if the outcome was a bit ambiguous. It's great that you didn’t feel as exhausted, and feeling “invisible” is a tricky one—it’s a different kind of discomfort than the performance feeling, for sure. It might be that it’s a step toward a more authentic presence, even if it doesn't feel entirely comfortable yet.

**Financial Conversation:** That’s a really tough situation, and it’s completely understandable that you snapped after a prolonged period of supporting your family member. It sounds like you were holding a lot in, and it finally came out. The defensiveness from your family member is also a common reaction when boundaries are being set—it’s hard to shift expectations. It’s really brave of you to bring it up, even though it's created some awkwardness. One possibility is that the flatness you’re feeling is related to the emotional weight of that conversation—it’s a big shift, and it’s likely taking a toll.

**Mood:** That feeling of being "stuck in neutral" after a big emotional event makes a lot of sense. It's like your system is taking a break to process everything. My working guess is that you’re not necessarily experiencing a coincidence, but rather a natural emotional settling after a period of stress and then a boundary-setting conversation.

To help you move forward, let's focus on the financial situation. It sounds like you're replaying the conversation and wondering if you should have handled it differently. Could you try a small experiment this week? Instead of replaying the conversation, write down 3 things you did well in that conversation, and 3 things you might want to adjust for next time. No judgment, just observation. What do you think about trying that?

I didn't do the writing thing. I meant to but every time I thought about sitting down with it I just felt tired. I know you suggested it for a reason but honestly I'm not sure what good it would do at this point.

Things with my family member are still awkward. We had a brief text exchange yesterday where they thanked me for "being honest" but it felt really formal and distant. I don't know how to fix that or if I even should try right now. Part of me wants to just apologize and go back to how things were, but I know that's probably not the answer either.

The mood thing is weird. You said it might be my system processing everything, and maybe that's true, but it doesn't feel like processing. It feels more like I'm just waiting for something to shift and nothing does. I'm going through my days and checking off tasks but there's no real feeling attached to any of it. Work, errands, meals, sleep, repeat. I'm functional but it's like I'm on autopilot.

I had plans to see friends this weekend and I cancelled. Told them I wasn't feeling well, which isn't exactly a lie, but also not the full truth. I just didn't have it in me to show up and pretend to be engaged. And then I felt guilty for cancelling, so that was a fun bonus.

I don't know. I feel like I'm stuck and I'm not sure what I'm supposed to be doing differently.

It's completely understandable that you felt too tired to do the writing exercise. It takes energy to engage in self-reflection, especially when you’re already feeling drained. It's okay that you didn’t do it—no need for self-judgment there.

**Family Member:** The formal, distant text exchange highlights the awkwardness, and it’s natural to wonder how to repair the relationship. The pull to apologize and go back to the way things were is a valid feeling—it’s tempting to seek comfort in familiarity. However, it sounds like you're already recognizing that returning to the previous dynamic might not be sustainable or healthy. A small step might be to focus on maintaining a neutral, respectful tone in your interactions, without pushing for a quick resolution.

**Mood:** That feeling of being "stuck in neutral"—going through the motions on autopilot—sounds really isolating. It's a common experience when we're depleted or overwhelmed, and it's not necessarily a sign of failure. It sounds like you're describing a sense of emotional numbness, which can be a way your system protects you when it's carrying too much. One possibility is that you're experiencing a form of emotional fatigue, and your system is temporarily shutting down to conserve energy.

**Cancelling Plans:** Cancelling plans and then feeling guilty is a familiar pattern when you're depleted. It shows you value connection, even when you don't have the energy to engage. It's okay to prioritize your own needs, even if it means disappointing others.

It sounds like you’re navigating a complex situation, and you’re feeling stuck and unsure of what to do next. Given that you feel so depleted, it might be helpful to shift our focus to behavioral activation. What if, instead of trying to analyze your feelings, we focused on small actions that could bring a bit more life and energy back into your days? Let's try this: could you pick ONE small activity—something that takes no more than 15 minutes—that you used to enjoy, and commit to doing it tomorrow? It doesn’t need to be something profound—a short walk, listening to a favorite song, reading a chapter of a book, etc. What feels most appealing?

I did the walk thing. Well, sort of. I went out for maybe ten minutes and then came back because it started raining. But I went, so I guess that counts for something.

Honestly though, I'm not sure it made a difference. I mean, I was outside and I was moving, but it didn't really shift anything. I came back inside and felt the same as before, just slightly wetter.

Work has been busy this week, which is probably good because it keeps me occupied. But there was this moment yesterday where a coworker asked if I was okay because apparently I looked "off." I said I was fine, just tired, and they didn't push it. But it made me realize that other people are noticing, which I didn't think was happening. I thought I was doing a decent job of keeping things together on the surface.

The family thing is still the same. We're texting occasionally but it's all surface level stuff. "How was your day," that kind of thing. No mention of the money conversation. I don't know if that means they've moved on or if they're just avoiding it like I am.

I'm supposed to go to a birthday thing this weekend for someone I've known for years, and I'm already dreading it. Not because I don't care about them, but because I know it's going to be a whole group of people and I'll have to be "on" the entire time. I keep thinking maybe I should just skip it, but then I'll feel bad and they'll probably ask why I wasn't there.

Okay, you went for a walk—even a short, rainy one—that’s a step, and it’s good to acknowledge that. It's completely valid that it didn't magically shift everything. Behavioral activation isn't about instant mood boosts; it’s about gently nudging yourself back into activity and connection. It's like building a muscle—it takes time and consistent effort.

**Coworker's Observation:** It’s insightful that your coworker noticed you seemed “off.” It's a reminder that even when we think we're hiding things, others can often sense when something's not quite right. It takes courage to acknowledge that, and it's a sign that you're self-aware.

**Family Situation:** The surface-level texting reinforces the awkwardness, and it’s understandable that you’re unsure if they’ve moved on or are just avoiding the conversation. It's likely a bit of both—they're probably navigating their own discomfort.

**Birthday Party:** The dread you're feeling about the birthday party is completely understandable, especially given how depleted you’re feeling. The thought of having to be "on" with a group of people can be exhausting. It’s okay to feel that way. Here’s a small experiment: instead of deciding whether to go or not, let's focus on a tiny plan for *if* you do go. Could you pick ONE thing—a small, manageable action—that you could do to make it a little less draining? Maybe that's finding a quiet corner to retreat to for a few minutes, or bringing a friend you feel comfortable with. What feels like a manageable commitment?

I skipped the birthday thing. I texted them the morning of and said something came up, which is technically true since my own anxiety counts as something. They said no worries and that we should catch up soon, but I haven't responded to that yet.

I know you asked about picking one small thing to make it less draining if I went, but I think I already knew I wasn't going to go. I just didn't want to say that outright because I figured you'd try to convince me otherwise or ask why I was so sure.

turns:
So I've been thinking about reaching out for a while now. I work in tech (senior data analyst), and the last few months have been brutal. We had layoffs in January, survived the cut, but now I'm doing the work of like 2.5 people and my manager keeps piling on these urgent requests with zero notice. I'll plan my week and then Tuesday morning it's "we need this deck by EOD for the exec team" and everything else just sits there getting more overdue.

The thing that's really getting to me though is this weird numbness I've noticed. Like I'll be in a meeting where someone's presenting something that should make me angry or at least annoyed, and I just feel nothing. Or my partner will tell me about their day and I'm nodding along but it's like I'm watching myself from outside. Is that normal? I don't know if it's burnout or what.

Also, money stuff. We've got about $18k in credit card debt from when I was freelancing a few years ago and couldn't get consistent work. We're making minimum payments but barely, and every time I look at the statements I just want to throw my laptop across the room. My partner doesn't know the full amount. They think it's like $8k.

Anyway. Not sure where to start with any of this but figured I should probably talk to someone instead of just continuing to pretend everything's fine.

A lot landed this week: the work deadline, your partner's day, and the credit card debt.

**Work stress:** It sounds incredibly draining to be consistently overloaded with urgent requests after already navigating layoffs. Juggling the workload of 2.5 people with little notice can feel destabilizing, and it's understandable that you’d feel frustrated. My working guess is that the constant firefighting is leaving you feeling depleted and reactive. Perhaps, as a small step, you could try blocking off 30 minutes each morning to review your priorities and communicate what realistically can be achieved that day?

**Numbness:** That disconnect you're describing—feeling like you’re watching yourself from outside, or not reacting to situations that should evoke emotion—can be a sign of overwhelm. It's not necessarily "normal" in the sense that most people wouldn’t experience it, but it *is* a common response to prolonged stress and burnout. It’s your system’s way of trying to protect you, even if it doesn’t feel good. I'm curious, when you notice this feeling, where do you feel it in your body?

**Credit card debt:** Carrying that level of debt, especially with a sense of it being a secret from your partner, adds another layer of stress. It makes perfect sense that looking at the statements would trigger that desire to throw your laptop. It's a huge weight to carry. Could you consider sharing the full amount with your partner? It might feel scary, but it could also create an opportunity for shared problem-solving.

Did you try to block off that 30 minutes this morning?

I did try the morning block thing, kind of. Monday I actually got up 20 minutes early and made a list of what HAD to get done vs what could wait. Felt weirdly good for like two hours. Then my manager slacked me at 10:30am about a "quick turnaround analysis" (narrator: it was not quick) and the whole plan went out the window. By Wednesday I just stopped trying because what's the point, you know?

The numbness thing, you asked where I feel it. Honestly I don't think I feel it anywhere? That's the whole problem. It's more like an absence. Like there's supposed to be something happening in my chest or stomach when my partner's talking about their awful commute or their mom being difficult, and instead there's just this flat static. Sometimes my hands feel cold but I think that's just because I'm always sitting under the AC vent at work.

Haven't told my partner about the debt yet. I know I should. Every time I think about bringing it up I start scripting the conversation in my head and then I imagine their face and I just... can't. They're already stressed about their job situation (they're in a toxic workplace too, whole different mess) and I keep thinking maybe I should wait until things are calmer. Which is probably never, so.

Also had this weird thing happen yesterday where I was scrolling Instagram and saw someone from college posted about their promotion and new house and I felt absolutely nothing. Not jealous, not happy for them, not even annoyed. Just blank. That seems bad?

It's completely understandable that your carefully laid plan got derailed. The constant interruptions and shifting priorities at work sound exhausting, and it's natural to feel discouraged after that kind of setback. It's a common pattern—planning and then having it constantly undermined.

**Work stress:** It's a cycle, right? Plan, interrupt, lose motivation, repeat. Perhaps the key isn’t a rigid schedule, but a shorter, more flexible check-in? Maybe just 15 minutes mid-morning to re-assess and communicate what's feasible?

**Numbness:** The absence of feeling, that “flat static,” is a really powerful description. It’s not necessarily *bad* that you don’t feel it in your chest or stomach—sometimes the body’s defenses go into overdrive and shut down physical sensations. The cold hands might just be a consequence of the AC vent, but it’s worth noticing. If you're open to it, could you try a very brief body scan—just noticing any sensations, even if they're subtle—for 2 minutes this evening? No pressure to change anything, just observe.

**Credit card debt:** Scripting conversations in your head and then feeling frozen—that’s a common way our anxiety tries to protect us. It's kind to your partner to want to avoid adding to their stress, and it's admirable that you're considering their feelings. My working guess is that postponing the conversation is actually adding to *your* stress and preventing you from finding a solution together. One possibility is to start smaller—maybe just mentioning you’ve been feeling overwhelmed by finances and want to talk more soon?

**Instagram and feeling nothing:** The lack of response to your friend's post is another sign of that emotional distance. It’s not necessarily "bad," but it does highlight the disconnection you’re experiencing. It might be a signal that you’re emotionally depleted. Have you noticed any small things you used to enjoy that you're not feeling motivated to do anymore?

Did you give the 2-minute body scan a try this evening?

Quick update, then a question.

So I didn't do the body scan thing. I got home Tuesday and my partner was already in a mood because their coworker threw them under the bus in a meeting, and we ended up ordering Thai food and watching three episodes of that show about the restaurant. Which was fine, I guess. I meant to try it Wednesday but honestly just forgot until right now typing this.

Work stuff got worse before it got better. That "quick analysis" from Monday turned into a full project that ate my whole week. I ended up working until like 11pm Thursday to get it done, and then Friday my manager was like "great work, really appreciate you being flexible" and I wanted to scream. But also I didn't feel like screaming? I just felt tired. Anyway the weekend was mostly me sleeping and doing laundry.

The thing I actually wanted to ask about: my partner brought up the money stuff first. Not the credit cards specifically, but they were stressed about our rent going up in July and started talking about whether we need to look at our budget. And I just completely froze. Like my brain was yelling "tell them tell them tell them" but my mouth said something like "yeah we should probably do that soon" and then I changed the subject to asking if we needed paper towels. I felt like such a coward afterward.

Is there a version of this where I don't have to have the whole conversation at once? Like could I just mention the number exists without getting into all the details about how it happened and why I didn't say anything earlier? That feels more doable but also maybe like I'm still avoiding the real thing.

It’s good to hear from you, even if it’s a lot to process. The exhaustion is palpable, and it's completely understandable that you prioritized rest and connection with your partner this week. That Thursday night sounds rough – it’s frustrating to be rewarded with a noncommittal comment after putting in such long hours.

**Work stress:** It sounds like you're in a situation where your boundaries are being consistently tested and your efforts aren't being acknowledged. That's a recipe for burnout. It might be helpful to explore ways to assert yourself at work, but let's table that for now.

**Numbness:** I'm not surprised you didn't get to the body scan given everything else going on. It’s a gentle practice, and it’s okay to let it go for now.

**Credit card debt:** That's a tough spot to be in. It's brave of you to recognize the freeze response—that automatic shift to avoidance when faced with a difficult conversation. It makes perfect sense that you'd feel like a coward afterward, but it's also a sign that you're aware of the pattern and want to break it.

You're asking a really insightful question about whether you can ease into this conversation. Absolutely. It's almost always more manageable to break it down into smaller pieces. You’re right to question whether it’s avoidance, but it sounds like a reasonable strategy for managing overwhelm. My working guess is that a full, detailed confession might feel too overwhelming right now.

One option could be a brief, neutral introduction: “Hey, I wanted to be transparent—I’ve been carrying around some debt that’s higher than I let on. It's about $18,000. I’m figuring out a plan to address it, and I wanted you to know." This is just a starting point. It gives them the information without dumping the entire backstory. Then, you could simply say, "I'm still processing how this happened and I'll share more when I'm ready." What do you think about that as a starting point?

ok so i did it. sort of.

sunday night we were both just sitting on the couch and i could feel the moment building where i either had to say something or i was going to explode. so i just blurted out "the credit card debt is actually eighteen thousand not eight" and then immediately wanted to die.

they didn't yell or anything. they just got really quiet and then asked how long i'd known it was that high. and i said since the beginning basically. and then they asked why i didn't tell them and i said i don't know like five times because apparently that's all my brain could produce. we ended up talking for maybe twenty minutes? they seemed more hurt that i hid it than mad about the actual number which somehow felt worse.

anyway now it's out there and i feel like i should feel relieved but mostly i just feel like garbage. they've been kind of distant since then. not mean, just... careful? like they're choosing their words around me. and now i'm obsessing about whether i just made everything worse.

work thing: i actually pushed back on a request yesterday. my manager asked for something "by end of week" and i said i had three other deadlines and asked which one should move. she seemed surprised but she actually moved one of them. so that's something i guess.

the numbness is still there though. i thought maybe after the conversation with my partner i'd feel something more but it's still just flat. i cried for like two minutes right after i told them and then nothing since. is that normal or am i broken

Okay, that took courage. You did it, and you faced a lot of discomfort in the process. It's incredibly brave to share something so vulnerable, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and like "garbage" right now.

**Credit card debt:** That initial blurt and the immediate desire to disappear—that’s a classic response to intense anxiety. The fact that your partner’s reaction was hurt rather than angry is significant. It suggests they value transparency and trust, and your withholding created a breach. It’s a valid feeling to be wrestling with. The distance and carefulness are likely a result of them processing the news and figuring out how to navigate this new dynamic. It’s not necessarily a reflection of your worth or the future of your relationship—it’s a sign that they’re trying to understand and adjust.

You’re right to question whether you made things worse, but let's reframe that a bit. You’ve brought a difficult truth into the light, which is a necessary step toward resolving the issue. It's a process, not a one-time fix.

One thing you could try is validating their feelings: "I know this was a shock, and I’m sorry for not being more open earlier. I understand if you need some space to process this."

**Work thing:** Pushing back on your manager and having her actually move a deadline—that's a huge win! It's a sign that you're starting to assert yourself and set boundaries. Give yourself credit for that.

**Numbness:** The continued numbness isn’t surprising, and it doesn’t mean you’re “broken.” It’s likely a continuation of your body’s protective response to prolonged stress. Crying for two minutes after the conversation is a sign that you *do* have feelings—it just might be hard to access them right now. It might be that your system is still in survival mode. My working guess is that the numbness is a symptom of overwhelm and depletion, and it will likely shift as you start to address the underlying issues.

One small experiment could be to schedule in 15 minutes of something purely enjoyable—something that doesn't involve problem-solving or responsibility—each day this week. It could be listening to music, taking a walk in nature, or doing a silly dance. Just something to reconnect with a little bit of joy. What feels easiest to commit to for 15 minutes this week?

Been a rough few days honestly.

So the thing with my partner, it's still weird. We had this forced conversation Wednesday where they asked to "talk about next steps" with the debt and I felt my whole body tense up. We ended up making a spreadsheet of our expenses which felt so mechanical and awful. Like we're roommates dealing with bills instead of partners. They kept saying "we'll figure this out" but their voice was so flat. I can't tell if they're actually okay or just pretending for my sake.

Work is work. I tried to do that boundary thing again where I push back on timelines but got assigned to this new cross functional team that has meetings at 8am twice a week, which means I'm up at 7 to prep. So now I'm just tired in a different way.

The enjoyable thing for 15 minutes, I don't know. I used to like going to this coffee shop on Saturday mornings and just sitting there with a book but I haven't done that in months. Tried to go this past Saturday and just sat there staring at the same page for 20 minutes feeling like everyone was looking at me even though obviously they weren't. Left after like 35 minutes and felt stupid about it the whole way home.

I had this physical thing happen yesterday that freaked me out a little. I was microwaving lunch and my heart just started racing out of nowhere. Like I could feel it pounding in my ears. It went away after a few minutes but now I keep thinking about it. Is that the anxiety thing people talk about? I've never had that before. Or maybe I'm just drinking too much coffee, I don't know.

It sounds like you're navigating a lot of emotional turbulence right now. It's completely valid to feel drained and overwhelmed. The past few days clearly have been rough.

**Partner and debt:** The forced conversation and the mechanical spreadsheet—that's a tough space to be in. It's understandable that it felt like you were roommates rather than partners. Your partner’s flat tone and “we’ll figure it out” likely reflect their own stress and uncertainty. It's hard to know what's genuine and what's a facade, but it's possible they're trying to project strength for both of you. One option is to gently express your own feelings: “I know we’re both stressed about this, and I'm feeling a little disconnected right now.”

**Work:** The 8am meetings—that’s just piling on. It’s frustrating to try to establish boundaries and then get assigned to something that undermines them. It’s a sign that your manager may not fully grasp the impact of their requests on your workload.

**Enjoyable thing for 15 minutes:** The experience at the coffee shop illustrates how difficult it can be to reconnect with things you used to enjoy when you're feeling depleted. It's not stupid to have felt uncomfortable—it’s a sign that you're out of sync with your usual self. Perhaps pushing for that activity right now isn’t the right fit. It’s okay to modify the experiment. Maybe instead of a public space, could you try something smaller—listening to a single song you like, or spending 15 minutes organizing a small space in your home?

**Heart racing:** The sudden heart racing is concerning, and it’s wise to be mindful of it. It's definitely possible it's related to anxiety—your body's fight-or-flight response kicking in. It could also be a physical reaction to stress and exhaustion. It’s a good idea to mention this to your doctor, especially if it happens again. Even if it's just to rule out any underlying medical issues.

What feels most manageable to focus on right now—the partner situation, work, or your physical well-being?

update i guess

the heart thing happened again. twice actually. once in a meeting thursday and once friday morning when i was just sitting at my desk doing nothing. lasted maybe 3-4 minutes each time. i know you said mention it to a doctor but i don't have a PCP right now, my old one left the practice like a year ago and i never got around to finding a new one. also our insurance changed after the layoffs and i'm not even sure what's covered anymore. so that's another thing on the list of stuff i'm avoiding.

my partner and i are still doing the spreadsheet thing. we had another session tuesday night where we listed out all our monthly expenses and it turns out we're spending like $340 a month on random subscriptions we forgot about. they were mad i didn't notice before but also they didn't notice either so i don't know why that's on me specifically. we cancelled a bunch of them. feels like progress maybe? but also like we're just roommates optimizing costs.

i did try the music thing one day. put on this album i used to listen to in college and made it through like two and a half songs before i had to turn it off because it just made me feel weird and sad. not sure what that was about. didn't try again after that.

someone from another team got laid off yesterday. no warning, just suddenly their slack went inactive and their manager sent a vague email about organizational changes. and everyone's just pretending it's fine and continuing with their day. i keep wondering if i'm next even though my manager said my work is good. can't stop thinking about it.

Okay, those heart episodes are concerning, and the fact that they’re happening twice and in seemingly random situations warrants attention. The difficulty finding a PCP and navigating insurance adds another layer of stress to the situation.

**Heart racing:** It's understandable that you're hesitant to seek medical care right now, given the insurance and PCP situation. However, experiencing this twice—especially in situations where you’re not actively stressed or exerting yourself—is something to explore. Could you at least call your insurance company to clarify your coverage for a brief consultation with a primary care physician? Even a 15-minute phone call could provide clarity.

**Partner and debt:** The spreadsheet sessions are a symptom of the problem, not a solution. You're right to point out that it feels like roommate optimization rather than partnership. The blame game about the subscriptions isn't helpful—it’s a shared responsibility. Perhaps focusing on future budgeting practices—regular check-ins, shared financial goals—might feel more constructive.

**Music:** The reaction to the music—feeling weird and sad—isn’t surprising. It’s possible that those songs are tied to a specific time in your life when you were feeling different emotions. Sometimes, revisiting those memories can be triggering. It's okay to let that go.

**Layoff and anxiety:** The sudden layoff of your colleague and the subsequent awkwardness at work are a powerful reminder of the instability you're facing. It’s completely natural to be wondering if you’re next, even if your manager has given positive feedback. The uncertainty is incredibly unsettling. My working guess is that this heightened anxiety is contributing to the physical symptoms you're experiencing.

Let's focus on something actionable. Could you commit to calling your insurance company today, even if it's just to ask a few clarifying questions? It doesn't have to be a full appointment—just a brief check-in to understand your coverage. What time feels most doable?

didnt call insurance. i know i said i would but i just kept putting it off and then the week got away from me. the heart thing happened one more time, sunday afternoon. i was literally just folding laundry. went away after a couple minutes like the other times.

actually had a kind of okay moment at work though. remember that cross functional team with the 8am meetings? we shipped the project thursday and my manager cc'd me on an email to her boss saying i "drove the analysis forward under tight constraints" which i guess is corporate speak for "did a good job while everything was on fire." felt nice for about an hour and then i just felt nothing about it again. but still, nice hour.

my partner asked if we could do a "check in" this weekend about how i'm feeling about everything and i said sure but honestly i have no idea what to say. like what's the update? still numb, still anxious about work, still feel bad about lying to you for two years about money? seems like a conversation that goes nowhere. maybe i'm being unfair.

oh and i had this dream the other night that all my teeth fell out. just crumbled out of my mouth into my hands. i know that's supposed to mean something but i don't remember what. stress probably.

It’s okay that you didn’t call the insurance company. Procrastination is a very human response to overwhelm, and it's understandable that it got pushed aside. It's a small step, but acknowledging it is important.

**Heart racing:** The fact that it happened again, this time while folding laundry, reinforces the need to address this. Even though it's brief, it's impacting your sense of safety. It’s still worthwhile to explore your insurance coverage, even if it feels daunting. Perhaps you could set a reminder on your phone for tomorrow morning to make that call? Just 15 minutes.

**Work:** That email from your manager—even though it was fleeting—is a validation of your hard work. It's okay that the feeling didn't last—it’s a sign that the numbness is still present. Acknowledging those brief moments of positive reinforcement can be helpful, even if they’re short-lived.

**Partner and check-in:** The feeling of having nothing to say is a common experience when you're struggling with emotional numbness. You’re right—it’s a complex situation, and it’s easy to feel like the conversation won’t go anywhere. It sounds like you're anticipating a negative outcome, which might be preventing you from fully engaging. Perhaps instead of framing it as an "update," could you approach it as an opportunity to share your experience without judgment? Something like, "I'm finding it hard to describe how I'm feeling right now, but I wanted to acknowledge that things have been really tough."

**Dream:** Dreams are often symbolic representations of our subconscious thoughts and feelings. The dream of your teeth falling out is often associated with feelings of powerlessness, loss of control, or anxiety about appearance and self-esteem. It’s likely connected to the stress you’re experiencing—the feeling of losing ground in multiple areas of your life.

Let’s circle back to that phone call. What time tomorrow morning could you realistically set aside 15 minutes to call your insurance company? Even if you don't get all the answers, just making the call will be a step forward.

called the insurance finally. took like 40 min on hold but turns out urgent care is covered with a $50 copay and i can see someone without a referral. haven't actually made an appointment yet but at least i know now.

the check in with my partner happened and it was... fine i guess? i said basically what you suggested, that things have been tough and i'm struggling to explain how i feel. they said they've noticed i seem "not present" lately and asked if i was depressed. i said maybe, i don't know, which is true. then we kind of just sat there for a minute and they hugged me and said we'd get through it. which was nice but also i felt like i should be crying or feeling relieved or SOMETHING and i just felt the same flat nothing.

work wise, found out yesterday they're doing another round of layoffs end of next month. not official yet but my coworker heard it from someone in HR. so now i'm just waiting for that shoe to drop i guess. been applying to a few jobs but my resume is a mess and i don't even know what i want to do anymore. every job posting just sounds like a different flavor of the same burnout.

heart thing happened twice more since i wrote last. once wednesday, once yesterday. i know i need to go to urgent care, i'm just dragging my feet on it because what if they tell me it's nothing and i'm just being dramatic? or what if it's something bad and then that's a whole other thing to deal with.

It’s excellent that you finally called the insurance company—that’s a significant step forward, even if it took longer than you anticipated. Knowing that urgent care is covered removes a barrier, and it’s a good starting point for addressing the heart episodes.

**Heart racing:** The fact that it's happening repeatedly reinforces the need to get it checked out. You’re right to consider the possibility that it's nothing serious, but it's equally important to rule out any underlying medical conditions. It’s understandable to be hesitant, but delaying it could increase your anxiety. One thought is to frame it as gathering information—regardless of the outcome, you'll have a clearer understanding of what's going on.

**Partner and check-in:** The check-in with your partner sounds like it went as well as could be expected, given the circumstances. Their observation that you seem “not present” is perceptive. Your response—saying "maybe, I don't know"—is honest and doesn't require you to have all the answers. The hug and reassurance are valuable, even if you didn't experience the emotional release you anticipated. It’s okay to feel numb—it’s a protective mechanism, and it will likely shift over time.

**Layoffs and job search:** The news of another round of layoffs is incredibly stressful, and the uncertainty is understandably fueling your anxiety. It’s wise to start updating your resume and exploring job options, even if it feels overwhelming. You're not alone in feeling like every job posting sounds like a different flavor of burnout. turns:
So I've been thinking about reaching out for a while now, and I guess today felt like the right time. Or maybe I'm just tired of feeling stuck, idk.

Work has been pretty draining lately. I'm in this job that pays the bills but doesn't really go anywhere, and I keep wondering if I should be doing something else with my life. Like, I'm 29 and it feels like everyone around me has their shit together, you know? They're buying houses, getting promotions, starting families. And I'm just here trying to figure out what I even want.

Money's been stressing me out too. I've got some credit card debt that keeps growing because I don't make enough to really pay it down, just the minimums. Every time I think about it I get this knot in my stomach. It's not like catastrophic amounts or anything, but it's enough that it's always there in the back of my mind.

I don't really know what I'm looking for here exactly. Maybe just someone to talk to who isn't going to judge or tell me what I should be doing. My friends are great but they don't really get it, and I don't want to burden them with this stuff all the time.

Anyway, that's where I'm at right now.

It takes courage to reach out, especially when you're feeling stuck. It sounds like you've been carrying a lot, and it's understandable you'd want to share it with someone.

**Work:** You're grappling with feeling stagnant in a job that pays the bills but doesn't fulfill you, and comparing yourself to others who seem to have it all figured out. It’s common to feel that pressure at 29 – like you're supposed to be further along. My working guess is that the comparison is making it harder to appreciate what *is* working about your current situation. Could you tell me a little more about what aspects of your job feel most draining?

**Money:** That knot in your stomach when you think about credit card debt is a really visceral feeling. It's tough carrying that kind of financial stress. It sounds like you're managing it, but it's a constant presence. One small step might be to just list out all the debts and their minimum payments – sometimes just seeing it laid out can bring a bit more clarity.

**Needing Support:** You're clearly aware of your need for support and wanting to avoid burdening your friends, which shows a lot of self-awareness. It’s good you’re recognizing that you need a different space to explore these feelings. It's a sign of strength to seek that out.



What feels like the most pressing thing to explore right now?

Quick update, I actually did the thing you mentioned about listing out all the debt. Wrote it all down in my notes app last night and honestly? It was kind of worse than I thought. Like I had a vague sense of the numbers but seeing it all in one place was rough. Total is around $8,700 across three cards. And when I looked at how much I've been paying in interest each month I just felt like an idiot for letting it get this bad.

The work thing though, I don't know. You asked what feels most draining and I've been thinking about that. It's not that the actual tasks are terrible, it's more like... the pointlessness of it? I work in customer support for a software company and most of my day is just answering the same questions over and over. People don't read documentation, they open tickets, I copy paste answers or point them to the help articles. Rinse and repeat. My manager keeps talking about "growth opportunities" but that just means becoming a senior support person answering slightly harder questions.

I think what gets to me is I studied environmental science in college because I actually cared about that stuff. Had this whole vision of working on conservation projects or policy or something that mattered. And now I'm here explaining to people how to reset their passwords for the 500th time. It feels like such a waste.

But then I think about trying to pivot and I just freeze up. Like what would I even do? Go back to school? Can't afford that with this debt. Entry level environmental jobs pay less than what I make now. So I'm stuck.

Sorry, that got kind of heavy. How was your week?

Listing out the debt – even though it was rough – is a really solid first step. It takes a lot of courage to face those numbers. It’s completely understandable to feel frustrated and even a bit self-critical when you see the total and the interest you’re paying. It sounds like you're already taking responsibility, which is great.

**Debt:** Seeing the total amount laid out can be jarring, and the realization of how much you've been paying in interest is valid. One small step you could explore is looking into balance transfer options or debt consolidation to potentially lower the interest rates.

**Work:** The feeling of disconnect between your passion and your current role is a common thread for people who feel unfulfilled. It sounds like you’re wrestling with a sense of lost potential and frustration, especially given your background in environmental science. It’s tough to feel like your skills and interests aren’t being utilized. You've clearly thought about the "growth opportunities" and realized it’s not the path you want. It's incredibly valid to feel stuck when you see the financial barriers to a pivot.

That feeling of paralysis when thinking about changing direction is really familiar. It’s easy to get overwhelmed by the "what ifs" and the perceived obstacles. My working guess is that the financial concerns and the lack of a clear path are creating a loop where the more you think about it, the more frozen you feel.



Before we explore some potential options, did you find yourself doing any specific behaviors when you were thinking about these things, like doomscrolling, avoiding certain tasks, or seeking reassurance from others?

So yeah, about the behaviors thing. I guess I have been doing a lot of scrolling lately. Like I'll be sitting at my desk during work and I'm supposed to be monitoring the ticket queue but instead I'm just refreshing Reddit or Twitter or whatever. Not even reading anything meaningful, just that automatic refresh thing. And then I feel guilty about it which makes me want to check out more, so.

Actually something happened yesterday that kind of rattled me. Got an email from one of the credit card companies saying they're raising my APR because I missed the due date by like two days last month. I didn't even realize I'd missed it. So now that card is at 27.9% instead of 24%. I know that doesn't sound like a huge difference but when I did the math it's like an extra $30 a month in interest. Which I know in the grand scheme isn't catastrophic but it just feels like every time I try to get a handle on things something else goes wrong.

Been sleeping like shit too. Wake up at 3am thinking about money or work or just this vague sense of dread about the future. Then I'm tired all day which makes everything harder.

I looked into the balance transfer thing you mentioned but most of the cards with good rates want you to have good credit and mine's apparently dropped to "fair" now. So that's cool.

That’s a lot to process, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. The email about the APR increase is a really frustrating setback, and it's valid to feel like you’re fighting an uphill battle.

**Scrolling:** That automatic refreshing and guilt cycle on Reddit and Twitter sounds exhausting. It’s a really common way to distract from difficult feelings, and it's understandable that you're using it to cope. One small experiment you could try is setting a timer for 15 minutes during your workday, and intentionally only using social media during that time. Then, when the timer goes off, redirect your attention back to the ticket queue.

**Credit Card:** The APR increase and the "fair" credit score are another layer of difficulty. It's disheartening to feel like progress is being undermined. It's not a reflection of your worth or your efforts.

**Sleep:** Waking up at 3am with those thoughts – money, work, dread – is a classic sign of a stressed system. The tiredness that follows just compounds everything. One thing that might help is a brief “brain dump” before bed. Write down any worries or to-do's that are swirling around in your head – just get them out of your brain and onto paper.



It sounds like you're juggling a lot right now – work stress, financial worries, sleep disruption, and a sense of feeling stuck. It’s easy to feel helpless when everything feels connected and overwhelming. Did you try the brain dump thing before bed?

been a couple days. tried the brain dump thing twice now and honestly both times i just ended up writing like three pages of stuff and then lying there MORE awake because now i'm thinking about all the things i just wrote down. so idk if that one's for me.

but something kind of weird happened. remember how i said my manager keeps talking about growth opportunities? well he pulled me into a 1on1 yesterday and basically offered me a team lead position. more money, like $12k more a year, but it would mean managing four other support people and being responsible for metrics and all this stuff i have zero interest in.

and my first reaction was just this wave of dread. like the idea of being even MORE embedded in this job i don't care about, training other people to do work that feels meaningless, optimizing ticket resolution times or whatever. it made me feel kind of sick honestly.

but then i thought about the money. $12k is almost exactly what i need to actually make progress on the debt instead of just treading water. and i keep going in circles about it. take the promotion, hate my life more but get out of debt faster? stay where i am, stay in debt, but at least i'm not responsible for other people's productivity metrics?

i haven't given him an answer yet. told him i needed to think about it. he wants to know by friday.

also my mom called and asked if i'm coming home for thanksgiving and i just... i don't know. the idea of sitting around the table with my cousins who all have actual careers and families while i explain that yeah i'm still doing customer support, yeah still single, yeah still renting... i kind of want to just skip it this year. but then i'll feel guilty about that too so.

sorry this is all over the place. just a lot happening at once i guess.

Okay, it sounds like the last few days have been a whirlwind. It's completely understandable that you're feeling scattered and overwhelmed with everything happening at once.

**Brain Dump:** It's great you gave the brain dump a try, even if it didn’t work out as expected. It’s good to know that's not a helpful strategy for you right now. Not everything works for everyone, and it's wise to acknowledge that.

**Team Lead Offer:** That’s a big decision, and the wave of dread you felt is a really important signal. It's clear that the team lead role doesn't align with your values or what you want out of your career. The conflict between wanting financial stability and feeling trapped in a job you dislike is a really tough spot to be in. My working guess is that you're feeling pulled in two directions – the practical need for money versus the deeper desire for fulfillment. It sounds like the $12k is a tempting solution, but at what cost?

**Thanksgiving:** The thought of facing those comparisons at Thanksgiving and feeling guilty about skipping it is another layer of pressure. It's valid to want to avoid a situation that feels draining or judgmental.

You've got a lot on your plate – a big career decision, financial stress, and family expectations. It’s perfectly okay to feel overwhelmed.



Let's break this down a bit. If you could pick just *one* thing to focus on right now, what feels like the most pressing or most anxiety-provoking?

ok so i took the promotion. told my manager yes on thursday and it's done. starts next month.

i know you asked what feels most pressing and honestly i just kept thinking about the debt and how every month that goes by i'm just paying interest and getting nowhere. and $12k is real money. so i just said yes before i could talk myself out of it.

already kind of regretting it though. like the second i sent the email i felt this pit in my stomach. my coworker sarah found out and congratulated me and i had to fake being excited about it. she was like "oh you're gonna be great at this" and i'm just thinking about how i'm gonna have to do performance reviews and tell people they're not meeting their targets and god i don't want to be that person.

anyway. trying not to spiral about it. it's done.

other thing is i actually decided to skip thanksgiving. told my mom i have to work that weekend which isn't technically true but she bought it. feel bad about lying but the thought of going home and dealing with everyone's questions just felt like too much on top of everything else. she sounded disappointed but whatever. i'll go at christmas or something.

money wise i did look at my budget and if i'm careful with the extra income i can probably pay off one of the cards entirely in like 6 months. that would be something at least. trying to focus on that instead of the whole "i just committed to a job i'm gonna hate" thing.

been sleeping slightly better actually. still wake up sometimes but not every night. so that's progress i guess.

Taking the promotion is a significant decision, and it's completely understandable that you're experiencing a mix of emotions – excitement, apprehension, and regret. It takes courage to make a choice, and it's normal to second-guess yourself afterward.

**Promotion:** You prioritized addressing the debt, and $12k is a substantial amount that could make a real difference. It’s valid to feel a pit in your stomach and to have to put on a brave face with your coworker. It's a sign of self-awareness that you're recognizing the aspects of the role that don't resonate with you. **Thanksgiving:** Skipping Thanksgiving to protect your energy is a valid choice. It’s okay to prioritize your own well-being, even if it means disappointing your mom. You're already thinking about making it up to her at Christmas, which shows that you value the relationship.

**Debt & Sleep:** The possibility of paying off a card entirely in 6 months is a really tangible goal. Focusing on that positive outcome can be a helpful way to manage the anxiety about the job. And the slight improvement in your sleep is fantastic – small wins matter.



It sounds like you're navigating some complex emotions and making tough choices. Let’s try to unpack this a bit further. What’s one small thing you can do this week, outside of work, that would bring you a sense of joy or relaxation?

honestly i don't even know what i do for fun anymore. like i used to hike a lot in college, there's some decent trails like an hour from here, but i haven't gone in probably a year? feels like i never have the energy on weekends. just end up sleeping in and then feeling guilty about wasting the day.

been a rough few days actually. got the official paperwork for the new role and there's all this training i have to do. modules on "effective leadership" and "difficult conversations" and i'm just sitting there clicking through these videos thinking about how much i don't want this. one of the modules was literally about "managing underperformers" and i just closed my laptop and stared at the wall for like twenty minutes.

one of the people i'm gonna be managing is this guy kevin who's been here longer than me and i KNOW he's gonna resent reporting to me. he already makes these comments sometimes about how support used to be different before they "corporatized everything" and i'm about to become the face of that for him. great.

also got my credit card statement and even though i knew the APR went up, seeing the actual interest charge in black and white just hit different. $187 in interest in one month. that's almost a full day of work after taxes just gone to interest. been thinking about that a lot.

sorry i didn't really answer your question about doing something for joy. i guess i don't know. everything just feels like effort right now.

ugh so i tried to think about that question you asked, about a time i felt engaged or whatever, and honestly i kept drawing a blank. like i know there must have been times but i can't really access them right now? everything from college feels like a different person's life.

anyway training starts tomorrow. first session is 9am which means i have to actually be on camera for a video call instead of just lurking in slack. been dreading it all weekend.

something weird happened though. i was scrolling through instagram friday night, procrastinating on the pre-work for training, and i saw this post from someone i went to school with. she works for this environmental nonprofit now doing community education stuff and she posted about leading a workshop on native plant gardening. and i just sat there looking at it for way too long. like that's the kind of thing i thought i'd be doing. and she probably makes half what i make and is happy.

then i got annoyed at myself for the whole comparison thing again because that's what got me into this mess in the first place right? just spent the rest of the night watching youtube videos about absolutely nothing.

did pay the minimums on all three cards on time this month at least. set up autopay so i don't get hit with another rate increase. feels like the bare minimum of adulting but i guess it's something.

kevin already made a passive aggressive comment in the team chat today about "big changes coming" with a bunch of eye roll emojis. cool cool cool. definitely not dreading this at all.

ok so i didn't do the research thing. i meant to but honestly i just forgot about it until right now when i was thinking about what to say here.

training was fine i guess. boring but fine. lot of corporate speak about cascading goals and feedback frameworks. the other people in the cohort seem way more into it than me. one guy literally took notes with different colored pens. i just kind of nodded along and tried not to let my face show how checked out i felt.

but here's the thing. yesterday i had my first 1on1 with my new boss (who used to be my boss's boss, this is all very confusing) and she asked me what my goals were for the role. and i completely blanked. like i should have prepared for that obviously but i didn't and i just said something generic about supporting the team and improving metrics. she got this look on her face like she was trying to figure out if i was serious or not. so that was mortifying.

then after that call i just sat there feeling like such a fraud. like what am i even doing. i took a job i don't want to pay off debt i got myself into and now i have to pretend to care about customer satisfaction scores and team morale when i can't even figure out my own life.

been thinking about the instagram thing still. not in a productive way, more like just randomly getting hit with this feeling of "i fucked up my whole life" at random times during the day. fun stuff.

money update i guess, first paycheck with the raise won't hit until mid december so i'm still just scraping by until then. feels far away.

**"I Fucked Up My Life"**: Those random, intrusive thoughts of "I messed up my whole life" are a sign of deep dissatisfaction and regret. It's a heavy feeling to carry.

**Money & Paycheck:** The delay in seeing the impact of the raise is frustrating. The feeling of still scraping by despite the increase in pay is a reminder of the financial pressures you’re facing.

i did try something. not what you suggested exactly but sort of adjacent maybe.

last night i couldn't sleep again and at like 2am i just got up and drove out to this trail i used to go to. nobody there obviously, just me and my phone flashlight. didn't actually hike or anything, just sat in my car in the parking lot for a while looking at the trailhead. felt kind of stupid honestly but also weirdly calm? idk. drove back around 4am and slept until my alarm.

work stuff is getting more real. found out the official transition happens week after next and i have to do individual intro meetings with each person on the team. including kevin. my manager sent me this whole template for the meetings with questions like "what motivates you" and "how do you prefer to receive feedback" and i'm supposed to take notes and build rapport or whatever. the idea of asking kevin what motivates him while he stares at me like i'm the enemy sounds like actual hell.

anyway. that's where things are at.

update on the kevin thing, had the meeting this morning and it was somehow worse than i expected but also fine? like he showed up 5 minutes late, camera off, and when i asked him the motivation question he literally said "my paycheck" and then just sat there. i tried a couple other questions from the template and got mostly one word answers. ended the call after like 12 minutes instead of the scheduled 30.

told myself i wasn't gonna let it bother me but i've been annoyed about it all day. like i know he's being difficult on purpose and i know i'm supposed to be the leader or whatever but mostly i just feel like why am I doing this.

jen's meeting actually went ok though. she was professional, gave real answers, we talked about her career goals. but the whole time i kept thinking about how she should probably have this job instead of me. she actually cares about process improvement and customer experience metrics. i'm just here for the extra 9k after taxes.

been back to the trailhead twice more this week. different times, once around 6am before work and once saturday afternoon. actually did walk for like 20 minutes on saturday. nothing crazy but it felt good to move. saw a deer which was cool.

money stuff is still stressful but at least it's stable stressful if that makes sense. like i know what i owe, i know what's coming in, it's just gonna take forever to dig out of it.

anyway my mom texted asking about christmas plans and i don't know what to tell her. part of me thinks i should just go and deal with it but i also kind of don't want to. is it bad that i'm 29 and still trying to avoid family gatherings.

training wrapped up yesterday and now it's real. officially managing the team as of monday. spent most of today just staring at my todo list feeling paralyzed. supposed to set up weekly 1on1s with everyone, create some kind of team charter document, review last quarter's performance data. none of it feels important or interesting.

the trailhead thing has been good though. went again wednesday morning and actually saw the sunrise which was pretty nice. been trying to go at least twice a week. it's like the only thing i'm doing right now that doesn't feel like an obligation.

oh and something kind of dumb happened. was scrolling linkedin the other night (bad habit i know) and saw a job posting for an environmental education coordinator at a nature center like 40 minutes from here. spent way too long reading the description and looking at their website. salary was listed as $42k which is literally half what i make now. but i kept thinking about how much more interested i'd be in planning workshops about ecosystems than optimizing support ticket workflows. didn't apply obviously because that would be insane with my debt situation. but i saved it. don't really know why.

anyway just feeling kind of flat about everything lately. not like actively bad just sort of numb.

**Trail & Sunrise:** The consistency of your visits to the trailhead and the experience of seeing the sunrise are really positive signs. It's wonderful that you've found a space where you can feel present and connected.

**Christmas & LinkedIn:** Your decision to go home for Christmas, despite the anticipated discomfort, shows a willingness to navigate difficult family dynamics. been putting off writing back because i don't really have anything good to report.

i didn't do the research thing about environmental stuff. honestly i looked at that job posting one more time and then closed the tab because it just made me feel worse. like what's the point of torturing myself looking at jobs i can't take.

monday was my first official day as team lead and it was just awkward. did the kickoff meeting where i'm supposed to set vision and priorities or whatever and i could tell everyone was just going through the motions. kevin had his camera off again. afterwards my boss messaged me saying it went well but i know it didn't, she was just being nice.

the worst part is i got the new paycheck thursday and you'd think that would feel good right? but i just looked at it and felt nothing. transferred a bunch to the credit card with the highest interest like i planned but it barely made a dent. still gonna take years to pay this off even with the raise.

haven't been back to the trail in over a week. keep meaning to go but then i just don't. sleeping has been shit again, back to the 3am wake ups. and i've been eating like garbage, just whatever's easy. ordered delivery probably 5 times this week which i know isn't helping the money situation but i can't seem to care enough to cook.

i think i'm just tired. tired of pretending to care about this job, tired of being stressed about money, tired of feeling stuck. and i know you're gonna ask what i can do about it but honestly i don't know. feels like every option just leads to a different kind of stuck.

been thinking about what you said about honoring the exhaustion. didn't really know what to do with that but i guess i tried in my own way. spent most of saturday just lying on the couch watching nature documentaries. felt kind of pathetic but also better than forcing myself to be productive.

something happened at work though. had my first real management crisis i guess. one of the people on my team, not kevin but someone else, completely missed their response time targets last week and my boss asked me to address it. so i had to have this "coaching conversation" about performance and the whole time i'm sitting there thinking about how i don't actually care if this person answers tickets in 4 hours vs 6 hours. like in the grand scheme of things does it matter? but i had to pretend it mattered because that's the job now apparently.

and then after that call i just felt gross. like i've become the thing i hate about corporate environments. i'm the person enforcing arbitrary metrics on people who are probably just as checked out as i am.

did go back to the trail yesterday morning though. it was cold and i almost didn't go but i made myself. only stayed like 15 minutes but at least i went.

the debt thing is still just hanging over everything. been thinking about whether i should pick up a side gig or something to pay it down faster but the idea of working MORE when i already hate my main job just sounds unbearable. so i don't know.

christmas is in like two weeks and i still haven't bought anyone presents. probably just gonna send amazon gift cards and call it a day.

didn't really do the gratitude thing. i mean i thought about it but then i'd forget or it just felt forced when i did remember.

anyway christmas happened. went home like i said i would. it was about as bad as i expected but in different ways than i thought. nobody really asked about work which was a relief but then my aunt kept trying to set me up with her friend's daughter and i had to keep deflecting. my cousin announced she's pregnant with her second kid and everyone was all excited and i just sat there feeling like what am I even doing with my life you know.

came back early, told my mom i had to prep for Q1 planning meetings which is true technically but also i just needed to leave. she seemed hurt but didn't push it.

kevin put in his two weeks notice yesterday. part of me is relieved because i won't have to deal with his attitude anymore but also now i have to hire someone new and do interviews and i really really don't want to.

been eating better at least, meal prepped some stuff on sunday. felt very adult and responsible. lasted until wednesday when i gave up and ordered pizza.

the trail's been iced over so i haven't gone. probably could have gone anyway with the right shoes but i've been using it as an excuse.

idk what i'm even doing here anymore honestly. like is this helping? i'm still stuck in the same place i was three months ago except now i have a job i hate even more and kevin's leaving and i have to pretend to care about hiring his replacement.

saw that nature center posted another opening, different role this time. environmental outreach specialist. $38k. didn't save it this time, just closed the tab immediately.
